Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Ultra-Low-Power MEMS-Based Implantable Biosystem for Restoring Vestibular Function-Platform for an Integrated Human-Centered Hybrid Biosystem

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ECCS-1055801
Pamela Bhatti, Georgia Institute of Technology
CAREER An Ultra-Low-Power MEMS-Based Implantable Biosystem for Restoring Vestibular Function-Platform for an Integrated Human-Centered Hybrid Biosystem

ABSTRACT
The objective of this research is to design, fabricate and validate an ultra-low-power implantable biomedical microsystem. The approach is to: (1) integrate an ultra-low-power biomimetic MEMS-based angular rotation sensor, (2) design and implement low power sensor interface and signal processing electronics, (3) fabricate highly flexible polymeric multichannel electrode arrays for electrical stimulation, and (4) integrate and validate the system in-vitro and eventually in-vivo. This will lead to an ultra-low-power fully implantable biosystem capable of activating vestibular nerve fibers in the inner ear serving to convey head rotation cues to the central nervous system serving to establish a sense of body position, maintain balance, and stabilize vision during movement.

Intellectual Merit: Individuals suffering from bilateral vestibular dysfunction experience postural imbalance, dizziness and nausea and currently have no effective therapeutic options. Vestibular and associated balance dysfunction often leads to falls falls are linked to high rates of mortality and morbidity in the elderly, contributing significantly to today?s skyrocketing healthcare costs. By integrating an ultra-low-power passive MEMS-based angular rotation sensor, to aggressively reduce power consumption, and by integrating highly flexible polymeric multichannel electrode arrays, to enable focused current delivery to vestibular nerves, a viable low-power implantable vestibular biosystem may restore vestibular function and improve the quality of life for these individuals.

Broader Impacts: The proposed sensing mechanism and low-power processing electronics may serve as a platform for an integrated human-centered hybrid biosystem such as a body worn device to measure angular head rotation, essential tremor or gait. To broaden participation of underrepresented groups, the PI integrates her research with outreach, mentoring, and teaching to engage students across the K-graduate continuum including Science Nights at an Atlanta science center, co-developing science modules with middle/high school teachers, developing a LabVIEW simulation of vestibular testing, and a graduate course addressing implantable biosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this research was to develop an intervention to assist individuals suffering from vestibular dysfunction. In particular, individuals suffering from bilateral vestibular dysfunction experience postural imbalance, dizziness and nausea and currently have no effective therapeutic options. The main outcome of this research is a low-power signal processor and electrical stimulator designed for implantation. Similar to how a cochlear implant conveys a lost sensation of sound, a vestibular stimulator was designed to specifically to stimulate vestibular nerves to overcome vestibular dysfunction. In additional to direct electrical stimulation, the research pursued a completely novel method to activate vestibular neurons through focused magnetic stimulation. This approach has the potential benefit of more focused stimulation than electrical stimulation, where current spread degrades performance. Furthermore, this strategy also allows for fully encapsulating the device, thereby further protecting sensitive neural tissue. Finite element modeling of the peripheral vestibular system indicated the ability of pulsed microcoils to create fields sufficient to active, vestibular neurons, with spatially restrictive fields, further corroborating the promise for micromagnetic stimulation.

Another unanticipated outcome was the extension from inertial sensing of head motion, to sensing to cardiac acoustic motion. Through a chest-worn linear accelerometer, a sensing method termed seismocardiography, acoustic signals indicating when the heart is mechanically stationary, can be predicted. This work strives to improves cardiac imaging of heart vessels to better assess and monitor cardiovascular disease by combining the electrocardiogram and seismocardiogram, to serve as a trigger signal for cardiac computed tomography imaging.

Three doctoral trainees were supported through this project, 12 journal papers were published, and 15 conference posters and abstracts were presented. The first trainee received the best paper award for the North America region at the 2014 IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology conference and is currently an assistant professor in the US. The second trainee completed a program in entrepreneurship during the course of her studies and is currently employed in the electronics industry. The third trainee won the 2017 Three Minute Thesis Competition at our institute and is and currently a postdoctoral researcher with the goal of becoming a professor. Six undergraduate students were involved in the research and maintained guided research toward realizing a head-worn vestibular training and head motion monitoring system for overcoming mild vestibular dysfunction. The transdisciplinary aspects of the research included the establishment of a junior investigator poster pitch competition at the international otolaryngology meeting. In addition to creating this career development opportunity for trainees in medicine, basic science, and engineering, the PI delivered two grand rounds presentations otolaryngology and surgery departments highlighting her group's vestibular research. Striving to engage elementary and high school students, the PI and her group facilitated hands-on workshops at the Fernbank Science Center Museum in Atlanta, GA.

The outcomes of this project also include curriculum development for both undergraduate students and graduate students. Neural engineering and neurophysiology content were created and disseminated for a combined undergraduate and graduate medical instrumentation course. In addition, the PI emphasized translational engineering in a course on entrepreneurship, as well as focused entrepreneurship training for investigators in clinical and translational science. Lastly, in the spirit of use-inspired engineering, the PI coached clinical and translational researchers, undergraduate and graduate students on how to translate discoveries to from the lab to the marketplace. One of the undergraduate teams coached by the PI is currently an NSF SBIR Phase II funded company.
